document.title: I think I lost my way?
document.description: Blog posts have their own pages. The content source is a markdown file, parsed to HTML by Contentlayer.

body.raw:
**Contentlayer makes working with content easy.** It is a content preprocessor that validates and transforms your content into type-safe JSON you can easily import into your application.

## Why I'm Learning Rust

_Oct 4, 2022_

I keep asking myself: Why learn Rust when there are so many other languages I could learn? Why not learn Go instead? Everyone seems to pit them against each other. Why not double down on TypeScript? Why even bother learning a new language or framework if itâ€™s unlikely Iâ€™ll get to use it for anything aside from hobby projects?

These questions are valid ones, but they are based upon a flawed premise. It is 100% okay for someone to learn anything without any good reason! Learning can be purely just for fun, based on a hunch, based on an intuition. So while I donâ€™t have great answers to those questions, I at least have some hopes and dreams and a few motivating factors.

## Why Rust

My first programming language was Java. My computer science teacher in high school made us print out our code to grade it. Iâ€™m not sure why, but thatâ€™s what he wanted.

Then I started programming in C# because XNA (Microsoftâ€™s game engine for indie Xbox 360 development) required it. Then I dabbled in ActionScript 3 for Flash programming, C++ for college classes, a bit of PHP, and somehow landed on using Ruby and JavaScript. Then 10 years flew by. Strange how time works. Iâ€™ve dabbled a bit here and there. A little Go. A little Haxe. But nothing aside from a few weeks or months of experimenting.

As Iâ€™ve grown as a developer, Iâ€™ve found myself longing to get a bit lower level. Iâ€™m thinking a lot more about performance and memory. Iâ€™m a bit tired of the slowness and memory usage of Ruby (and Rails). Sure, they work and are mature. But they are, in many ways, resource hogs. They donâ€™t encourage thinking about program structure and correctness. Performance just seems like less of a priority and concern. But Iâ€™d like to write more performant code. Iâ€™d like to understand threading and memory usage more. Iâ€™d like to build cross-platform tools and games and code.

The thought of writing lower level code that isnâ€™t C or C++ is appealing. I enjoyed coding in those languages over a decade ago, but they felt dated in many ways, like writing separate header files. Itâ€™s been too long for me to have any salient thoughts on them though. ðŸ˜…

Also, through TypeScript, Iâ€™ve been re-exposed to the joys of statically typed languages. Having a great language server with types increases confidence with coding and is much more ergonomic than having to look at the docs online whenever one wants to look something up. The idea of a performant, strongly-typed, modern language is extremely appealing!

Iâ€™m also continually annoyed by dealing with `nil` errors in Ruby and `null` and `undefined` errors in JavaScript. I understand why they exist, and they can be manageable, but to think that thereâ€™s another way is interesting to me.

## Programming Beyond the Web

Iâ€™ve primarily done web application development for the last 13 years. Itâ€™s enjoyable and ever-changing. But Iâ€™d like to do some other types of programming too. There are only so many web forms you can build before it begins to feel a bit rote. Game dev, desktop GUIs, command-line tools, networking codeâ€”Rust seems great for all of them. Thereâ€™s so much breadth to the types of programming out there that it feels like Iâ€™ve barely scratched the surface.

## The Promise of Polyglot

While there will surely be a bit of overhead of context switching between languages, I think learning a variety of languages will make me a better programmer overall. Rust, so far, seems like it will help me reframe how I think about programs and write my code. Thatâ€™s major! Breaking out of the paradig

`,(0,u.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:"The thought of writing lower level code that isn\u2019t C or C++ is appealing. I enjoyed coding in those languages over a decade ago, but they felt dated in many ways, like writing separate header files. It\u2019s been too long for me to have any salient thoughts on them though. \u{1F605}"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/clinton/Desktop/playground/my-personal-site/data/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-45492998-e874-43e7-bb87-fe6240b2c7e2.mdx",lineNumber:25,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,u.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:"Also, through TypeScript, I\u2019ve been re-exposed to the joys of statically typed languages. Having a great language server with types increases confidence with coding and is much more ergonomic than having to look at the docs online whenever one wants to look something up. The idea of a performant, strongly-typed, modern language is extremely appealing!"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/clinton/Desktop/playground/my-personal-site/data/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-45492998-e874-43e7-bb87-fe6240b2c7e2.mdx",lineNumber:27,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,u.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:"I\u2019ve primarily done web application development for the last 13 years. It\u2019s enjoyable and ever-changing. But I\u2019d like to do some other types of programming too. There are only so many web forms you can build before it begins to feel a bit rote. Game dev, desktop GUIs, command-line tools, networking code\u2014Rust seems great for all of them. There\u2019s so much breadth to the types of programming out there that it feels like I\u2019ve barely scratched the surface."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/clinton/Desktop/playground/my-personal-site/data/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-45492998-e874-43e7-bb87-fe6240b2c7e2.mdx",lineNumber:33,columnNumber:1},this),`
